Services, Trade–Public Services, and Digital Trade. Each questionnaire targets experts in their respective 
areas of expertise. A screener questionnaire is used to assist the selection of experts receiving the topic

IV. PARAMETERS 
 
To ensure data comparability across economies, the International Trade topic uses general and specific 
parameters for expert questionnaires and firm-level surveys. A parameter refers to an assumption made 
about the existence of trade flows by transport mode, trading partners, and WTO membership of a given 
economy. 
 
5.1 General Parameters 
 
To strike a balance between cross- country comparability and economy- specific representativeness, the 
International Trade topic employs the following general parameter.

5.1.1 Active Trade Flows by Transport Mode 
Justification: 
Depending on its physical and political geography, an economy’s trade flows may take place via maritime, 
air, or land-based routes. The regulatory frameworks and trade facilitation services differ across transport 
modes and have direct implications for the time and cost of importing and exporting. To enable meaningful 
comparison, it is therefore necessary to determine whether an economy has active trade flows across all 
transport modes or only a subset of them. For example, landlocked economies do not have active trade 
flows via maritime transport, and island economies do not have active trade flows via road transport. 
 
Application: 
This parameter applies to all Pillars. Specifically, it determines the applicability of the transport services 
subsectors measured in Pillars I and II , as well as the threshold pairs for assessing time and cost in the 
categories Compliance with Export Requirements and Compliance with Import Requirements in Pillar III. 
 
5.2 Specific Parameters 
 
Trade regulations and their applicability may also vary depending on an economy’s traded goods and 
services, and the ir trading partners. To strike a balance between cross- country comparability and 
economy‑specific representativeness, the International Trade topic em ploys the following specific 
parameters to provide contextual information for experts to identify the appropriate regulations to be 
assessed in different pillars. 
 
5.2.1 Services Sectors and Subsectors 
Justification: 
Regulation of trade in services varies at the subsector level. Considering the crucial role of certain service 
sectors as inputs and facilitators for international trade in goods, five subsectors across transport services 
and logistics services are selected as specific parameters for the International Trade topic: Maritime Freight 
Transport, Air Freight Transport, Road Freight Transport, Customs Brokerage, and Cargo Handling, 
Storage and Warehousing. 
 
Application: 
This parameter applies to indicators assessing trade in services in both Pillars I and II. Indicators measuring 
services classified under the Customs Brokerage and Cargo Handling, Storage and Warehousing subsectors 
are applicable to all economies. However, those covering the subsectors of Maritime Freight Transport, Air 
Freight Transport, and Road Freight Transport depend on the active trade flows by transport mode (see 
subsection 5.1.1). E conomies with active trade flows by maritime, air, and road transport modes are 
assessed on all three subsectors (Maritime Freight Transport, Air Freight Transport, and Road Freight 
Transport). Economies without active trade flows by a given transport mode are not assessed on the 
corresponding subsector. For example, landlocked economies are not assessed on questions related to 
Maritime Freight Transport, and i sland economies are not assessed on questions related to Road Freight 
Transport. 
 
5.2.2 Main Trading Partner(s) 
Justification: 
This parameter refers to an economy’s main trading partner(s) by different trade categories. While 
economies typically engage in trade with a wide range of partners, the intensity of these relationships varies. 
Trade intensity is influenced by factors such as geographical proximity, market size, and historical or 
institutional linkages. Identifying an economy’s main trading partner (s) is important because c loser 
cooperation and coordination with this ( these) partner(s) can bring the most benefits to the bus iness 
environment. Partner selections are conducted based on the UN Comtrade (for data on trade in goods) and

OECD-WTO Balanced Trade in Services (for data on trade in services) databases, using bilateral data for 
the period 2015-2019. 
 
Application: 
This parameter is used in Pillar I under Subcategories 1.1.3–Trade Cooperation (Goods) and 1.3.3–Trade 
Cooperation (Digital). In these contexts, main trading partners consistently refers to an economy’s top three 
trading partners in goods and services. This parameter is also used in Pillar I under Subcategory 1.2.3 –
Trade Cooperation (Services). In this context, main trading partners likewise refer to an economy’s top 
three trading partners in goods and services, except for the indicator International Road Freight Operations 
with Main Land Border Partner Permitted without Trip-Based Permits or Quotas, where the main trading 
partner refers to the adjacent economy connected through the main customs land border post, as determined 
by the value of land-based trade flows (see subsection 5.2.3). 
 
Moreover, t his parameter is used in Pillar II under the Subcategor ies 2.4.3–Coordinated Border 
Management (with Trading Partner(s)) and 2.4.4–Trusted-Trader Program. In these contexts, main trading 
partners generally refer to an economy’s top three trading partners in goods and services . An exception 
applies to indicators assessing bilateral operational coordination, specifically Main Customs Border Posts 
Recognize Inspections Conducted by a Main Trading Partner and Economy Aligns Border Operations at 
Shared Land Border , for which reference is made to a single main trading partner only. Where such 
indicators assess a seaport or airport, the main trading partner refers to the economy’s largest trading partner 
in goods only. Where they assess a land border, the main trading partner refers to the adjacent economy 
connected through the main customs land border post, as determined by the value of land-based trade flows 
(see subsection 5.2.3). 
 
5.2.3 Main Customs Border Posts 
Justification: 
This parameter refers to the main customs border posts by mode of transport: commercial seaport, cargo 
airport, and customs land border post. To measure trade infrastructure, it is important to identify the borders 
that are most relevant to the economy in terms of trade value. It is also crucial to differentiate the questions 
asked by mode of transport, as facilities, services and infrastructure can vary across different types of border 
posts (for example, between a seaport and a customs land border post) . The selection of the main borders 
by mode of transport is based on total trade value, calculated from data from ancillary government sources 
(such as statistical agencies) and confirmed by experts. 
 
Application: 
This parameter is used in Pillar II under S ubcategories 2.3.1–Infrastructure at Main Seaport, 2.3.2–
Infrastructure at Main Airport, 2.3.3–Infrastructure at Main Customs Land Border Post, 2.4.2–Coordinated 
Border Management (Domestic), and 2.4.3–Coordinated Border Management (with Trading Partner(s)). 
 
The applicability of the indicators on main commercial seaport, cargo airport, and c ustoms land border 
posts is determined based on whether an economy has any operational customs border posts in each of the 
three modes of transport at the time of the cut-off date. Economies with operational customs border posts 
in each mode of transport are assessed on questions covering all three customs border posts (seaport, airport, 
customs land border post). Economies without operational customs border posts in one or two modes are 
not assessed on questions related to the corresponding customs border posts . For example, landlocked 
economies are not assessed on questions related to seaports, and island economies are not assessed on 
questions related to customs land border posts.

5.2.4 WTO Membership 
Justification: 
An economy’s WTO membership status (that is, Member, Observer, or none). In the context of trade 
cooperation, this parameter provides the necessary context to assess the applicability of any WTO -related 
obligations. 
 
Application: 
This parameter is used in Pillar I under Subcategory 1.1.3–Trade Cooperation (Goods), to determine 
whether the indicator No Preferential Trade Agreement Not Formally Notified to the World Trade 
Organization is applicable or not.

6.3 Pillar III–Operational Efficiency of Exporting Goods, Importing Goods, and Engaging in 
Digital Trade 
 
Pillar III covers 9 indicators with scores ranging from 0 to 100 on firm flexibility (table 43). The scores on 
indicators under this pillar are assigned to firm flexibility only, as the indicators measure the time and costs 
incurred to firms as they import , export, and engage in digital trade. For example, longer clearance time 
and higher transaction costs hinder firms’ ability to conduct international trade, thus hampering firm 
flexibility. The scoring for each category under this pillar is as follows: 
 
6.3.1 Compliance with Export Requirements has three indicators with a total maximum score of 30 
points. Specifically, the Total Time to Comply with Export Requirements (Average) Subcategory 
has 1 indicator, the Total Time to Comply with Export Requirements (Dispersion) Subcategory has 
1 indicator and the Total Cost to Comply with Export Requirements Subcategory has 1 indicator. 
 
6.3.2 Compliance with Import Requirements has three indicators with a total maximum score of 50 
points. Specifically, the Total Time to Comply with Import Requirements (Average) Subcategory 
has 1 indicator, the Total Time to Comply with Import Requirements (Dispersion) Subcategory has 
1 indicator and the Total Cost to Comply with Import Requirements Subcategory has 1 indicator. 
 
6.3.3 Participation in Cross -Border Digital Trade has only one indicator Share of Trading Firms 
Exporting Digitally Ordered Goods with a total maximum score of 10 points. 
 
6.3.4 Perceived Major Obstacles: Customs and Trade Regulation, and Transportation has two indicators 
with a total maximum score of 10 points. Specifically, the Perceptions Index of Customs and Trade 
Regulations Being a Constraint Subcategory has 1 indicator, the Perceptions Index of 
Transportation Being a Constraint Subcategory has 1 indicator.

ANNEX B. INTERNATIONAL TRADE–ANNOTATED QUESTIONNAIRE 
 
Annex B consists of a Glossary and Annotated Questionnaires for International Trade in four areas: Trade 
Regulations–Goods; Trade Regulations –Services; Digital Trade; and Public Services. The Annotated 
Questionnaires provide the mapping between each indicator and the corresponding question(s). 
 
Glossary 
 
8th and 9th freedoms of the air: The eighth freedom of the air allows a foreign airline to operate flights 
within another economy between two domestic points as part of a service connecting to its home economy 
(so-called “consecutive cabotage”), while the ninth freedom allows a foreign airline to operate domestic 
flights within another economy entirely independent of its home economy (so- called “stand -alone 
cabotage”). 
Advance import deposits: Requirements that the importer should deposit a percentage of the value of the 
import transaction on a government account before receiving the goods, as defined in Section G11 of the 
International Classification of Non-tariff Measures (UNCTAD, 2019). No interest is paid on the deposits. 
Advance ruling: A binding decision issued upon request by customs or another competent authority before 
importation or exportation, stating how specific goods will be treated under customs law —typically their 
tariff classification, origin, and/or customs valuation. The r uling is binding on customs authorities for a 
stated period (unless revoked or modified under prescribed conditions). 
Air Service Agreement (ASA): An international agreement between two or more economies that sets out 
the rights, routes, and conditions for airlines to operate commercial air transport services across their 
territories. 
Air service license : An authorization granted by a national aviation authority that permits an airline to 
operate commercial air transport services for passengers, cargo or mail, subject to compliance with national 
and international laws and regulations. 
Airport slot: An authorization granted by a competent airport or air traffic authority for an airline to take 
off or land at a specific airport and time. 
Antidumping duties: Duties levied on the imports of a particular good originating from a specific trading 
partner to offset injurious dumping found to exist as a result of an investigation, as defined in Section D12 
of the International Classification of Non- tariff Measures ( UNCTAD, 2019). Duty rates are generally 
enterprise-specific. 
Binding deadline : A deadline established in the legal framework that gives rise to a substantive or 
procedural consequence if the authority fails to meet it (such as, automatic approval of an application, a 
right of appeal, or another corrective mechanism). 
Cabotage: The transport of passengers, goods or mail within an economy by a foreign carrier. Cabotage is 
generally restricted by national cabotage laws or cabotage rights, which are legal rules limiting the ability 
of foreign firms to operate in domestic transport markets. 
Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) : A global market -
based mechanism developed by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) that requires airlines

to offset the growth of CO₂ emissions from international flights above 2020 levels by purchasing eligible 
carbon credits. 
Cargo h andlers: Companies or individuals responsible for the physical handling of cargo ( including 
loading, unloading, and storage) at ports, airports, land border posts, inland container depots (ICDs), and 
other storage and warehousing facilities. 
Cash margin requirements: Requirements that the importer should deposit part of or the total amount of 
the transaction value in a commercial bank before the opening of a letter of credit or foreign exchange 
purchase, as defined in Section G12 of the International Classification of Non-tariff Measures (UNCTAD, 
2019). The funds must often be in foreign currency and remuneration, if any, is usually below market rates. 
Commercial cryptographic method or provider : A cryptographic algorithm, standard, or solution 
developed and used for commercial purposes, as well as the service provider offering its implementation. 
This excludes cryptography designed exclusively for military or state-security applications. 
Cross-border data flo ws / Cross-border data transfer : The movement or transfer of data or personal 
information between servers across country borders. 
Cross-border digital identity verification (eKYC): The electronic process of verifying the identity of 
individuals or entities across national boundaries using digital technologies. It enables institutions —such 
as banks, fintech companies, and digital service providers —to authenticate users from other jurisdictions 
without requiring physical presence. 
Customs-approved storage and warehousing facilities: Facilities authorized by customs for the storage 
of goods under its supervision, including customs-bonded warehouses, state warehouses, temporary storage 
facilities, and inland container depots (ICDs). 
Customs bonded warehouse: A building or other secured area in which dutiable goods may be stored, 
manipulated, or undergo manufacturing operations without payment of duty until they are cleared through 
customs. It may be managed by the state or by a private enterprise. In the latter case a customs bond must 
be posted with the government. 
Customs brokers/agents: Individuals or corporations that assist importers and exporters in meeting the 
requirements governing customs formalities. Customs brokers/agents manage the submission of necessary 
documentation and payments of duties and taxes to customs authorities on behalf of their clients. 
Customs union: An arrangement between two or more countries where they agree to eliminate tariffs and 
quotas on products within the customs union, and to apply a common external tariff (CET) with respect to 
imports from the rest of the world. 
Digital currency: A form of currency that exists only in digital or electronic form and includes Central 
Bank digital currencies, cryptocurrencies, digital currency service providers, digital currency wallet 
providers, amongst others. Digital currencies can substantially reduce transaction costs associated with 
cross-border transactions. 
Duty de minimis threshold: A valuation ceiling for imported goods, including documents and trade 
samples, below which no duty or tax is charged. 
Economic Needs Tests (ENTs): Regulatory mechanisms used by governments to assess market demand 
and economic conditions before granting licenses or permits to foreign firms or individual service providers.

They are usually based on criteria such as market capacity, domestic supply, competition, and potential 
economic impact. 
Electronic bill of lading: A bill of lading issued and maintained in electronic form that serves the same 
functions as a paper bill of lading, including as a receipt for goods, evidence of the contract of carriage, and 
a document of title enabling the transfer of rights and obligations under the contract of carriage. 
Electronic financial instruments: Financial instruments relevant for customs clearance that are issued, 
transmitted, and stored in electronic form, with equivalent legal effect to their paper -based counterparts. 
Examples include electronic letters of credit (e-LCs), electronic bank guarantees, electronic customs bonds, 
electronic transit guarantees, and electronic insurance certificates. 
Electronic Single Window (ESW): An official electronic platform that provides a single entry point for 
traders to submit, process, and obtain all documents and decisions required for customs clearance and 
related post-clearance procedures. An Electronic Single Window integrates multiple government agencies 
through one portal, enabling traders to complete all steps related to customs clearance and post -clearance 
benefits—including applications for certificates, clearance decisions, and tariff rebate claims—w ithout 
using separate systems or paper channels. 
Enquiry point: An official or office designated to deal with reasonable enquiries, including the provision 
of forms and documents to traders, and other interested parties on matters of importation, exportation, 
transit of goods, trade in services and digital trade. 
Environmentally Sound Management (ESM): Waste management procedures taking all practicable steps 
to ensure that waste are managed in a manner which will protect human health and the environment against 
potential adverse effects. 
Ex ante Regulatory Impact Assessment (RIA): Is a systematic, evidence-based process conducted before 
a decision is taken to adopt or amend regulation, used to assess the likely benefits, costs, and other impacts 
of the preferred option and feasible alternatives (including non-regulatory options). 
Export taxes and duties: Taxes collected on exported goods by the Government of the exporting country. 
Such taxes can be set either on a specific or an ad valorem basis, as defined in Section P42 of the 
International Classification of Non-tariff Measures (UNCTAD, 2019). 
Express shipments: Goods carried by an operator that provides expedited transport, customs clearance, 
and delivery services under a fast -track regime, usually supported by advance electronic information, 
simplified procedures, and guaranteed time-definite delivery. 
Foreign firms: Companies or individuals that are owned, controlled, or established outside the economy 
where they operate. 
Foreign ships: Vessels that neither fly the national flag nor are registered in the national ship registry. 
Formal public consultation: Official process conducted by government bodies or organizations to solicit 
feedback from citizens, stakeholders, or interested entities on proposed legislative or policy changes, or 
upcoming projects. Unlike informal dialogues, these consultations are systematically organized, follow a 
set protocol, and are part of the decision -making process, ensuring that the input collected is formally 
recognized and considered.

Free trade agreement: A treaty between two or more countries designed to facilitate trade and remove 
trade barriers, including tariffs and quotas. It encompasses various sectors such as goods, services, 
intellectual property, and investment. The agreement seeks to bolster economic cooperation and integration 
among its members, establishing shared trade regulations and standards. 
Globally Harmonized System for Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS): An internationally 
agreed-upon system to standardize chemical hazard classification and communication. It has been 
developed over several decades and is endorsed by the United Nations. 
Hazardous waste: Wastes with the potential to cause harm to human health or the environment if managed 
improperly. This notably includes waste with specific properties such as explosive, flammable, corrosive, 
poisonous, infectious, toxic, or ecotoxic. It also includes waste which, after disposal, can yield another 
material possessing any of the characteristics listed. 
IMO 2020 rule: The IMO 2020 rule limits the sulfur content in the fuel oil used on board ships operating 
outside designated emission control areas to 0.50% m/m (mass by mass). Alternatively, ships can use a 
system achieving the same level of sulfur oxide (SOx) emissions, such as exhaust gas cleaning systems 
("scrubbers"). This new limit was made compulsory following an amendment to Annex VI of the 
International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships (MARPOL). 
Import quotas and tariff -rate quotas: Quantitative import restrictions that limit the amount of specific 
goods allowed to enter a country within a set period, as defined, respectively, in Sections E2 and E6 of the 
International Classification of Non-tariff Measures (UNCTAD, 2019). A quota fixes a maximum volume 
or value of a product, while a tariff-rate quota permits limited imports at a lower tariff and applies a higher 
tariff beyond that limit. Safeguards (D3) and prohibitions (E3) are excluded from this definition. 
Institutionalized mechanism: a designated authority or a formal, published procedure (such as, portal or 
complaint-handling process), established by law/regulation or official policy, with public intake channels 
and defined steps/timelines. 
Justiciable commitments: Obligations set out in a free trade agreement or stand -alone international 
agreement (including annexes or side letters) that are currently in force and that (i) use mandatory language 
(such as, “shall” or “must”); (ii) are sufficiently specific to constrain implement ation discretion; and (iii) 
are enforceable through a designated dispute- settlement mechanism that issues binding decisions/awards 
(state-to-state panels or arbitration) or through domestic courts where the agreement ha s direct effect. 
Commitments arising solely from multilateral WTO membership (such as, GATT/GATS/TBT/SPS) are 
excluded. 
Legal enforceability: Pertains to the ability to compel parties to adhere to the terms of a contract or legal 
document. If a contract is enforceable, it means that if one party fails to meet their obligations, the other 
party can seek a legal remedy through the court system. Enforceabil ity ensures that contracts are not just 
legally valid but also actionable in practice and executed according to its terms. 
Legal framework: Rules, regulations and laws that make up the totality of the legislation applicable to 
international trade in a specific jurisdiction. This refers to national or federal legislation, rather than 
subnational rules (e.g. state -level laws). In the case of the European Union, this includes EU directives 
along with the national regulations and annexes that implement and supplement them. 
Legal safeguards for personal information: Legal protections that the agreement mandates or expressly 
recognizes for transfers of personal information. Examples are: adequacy/equivalence determinations; 
interoperable or mandated standard contractual clauses; recognition of approved corporate rules; cert ified

cross-border privacy frameworks; limits on onward transfers; transparency, redress, and independent 
oversight requirements. 
Local tax representative: An individual or entity appointed to act on behalf of a taxpayer in a specific 
jurisdiction, responsible for fulfilling the taxpayer's VAT/GST obligations. Some economies require a local 
tax representative when suppliers have tax obligations but no physical presence in the jurisdiction. 
Mandatory disclosure of source code (or algorithms) : A requirement in a law, regulation, or other 
binding measure that compels a person or firm to provide a government authority with access to, or transfer 
of (i) the human-readable source code of software, or (ii) the software’s algorithmic logic (such as, decision 
rules, model architecture/parameters where applicable), as a condition of importation, distribution, sale, 
use, certification/approval, licensing, or continued operation. 
Maritime single window: An official electronic platform that allows shipping agents, carriers, and other 
authorized parties to submit, through a single entry point, all information and documents required by the 
competent authorities for the arrival, stay, and departure of ships. A Maritime Single Window enables 
coordinated electronic reporting to multiple agencies — such as port, customs, immigration, health, and 
security authorities — so that all data are submitted once and shared automatically among the r elevant 
authorities, without the need for separate submissions or paper documents. 
Multiple-entry visa: A visa that allows a foreign national to enter and exit a country economy multiple 
times within a specified validity period, facilitating repeated travel for work or business without the need 
to obtain a new visa for each entry. 
National ship registry: A national ship registry is the official record an economy keeps of ships authorized 
to fly its flag, giving them its nationality and placing them under its legal responsibility, notably for safety, 
environmental, and labor standards. 
National Trade Facilitation Committee (NTFC): A multi-stakeholder body established to coordinate and 
oversee the implementation of trade facilitation measures, as set out in Article 23.2 of the WTO Trade 
Facilitation Agreement (TFA). 
Nationality or local residence requirements : Legal conditions that impose eligibility restrictions on 
foreign persons or enterprises, by limiting access to nationals of the economy or to those maintaining a 
local presence (that is, residency, establishment, local ownership, or local management), beyo nd the 
requirements applicable to the economy’s own nationals. 
Official electronic platform : A secure, user -authenticated website that is established, mandated, or 
formally authorized by one or more competent authorities for the submission, processing, and/or issuance 
of documents. All required steps in the relevant procedure should be able to be completed through this 
system without the need for paper -based submissions, including issuance of documents or certificates by 
the competent authorities. The system may take the form of an Electronic Single Window (ESW) or any 
other officially recognized digital platform. 
Official website: A website that is maintained by, or on behalf of, a domestic public agency (examples 
could be the central government, ministries, or other public bodies). The website should be publicly 
available, free of charge, and not require a login to visualize information. 
Permit to trade in endangered species: A written authorization issued by of the exporting, importing, or 
re-exporting country — based on a legal acquisition finding and a non-detriment finding (or equivalent) —

that authorizes the import, export, or re-export of a specimen (including parts and derivatives) of a species 
listed in the CITES Appendices I–III. 
Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs): Carbon-based chemical substances which, once released into the 
environment remain intact for long periods of time, spread throughout the environment, accumulate in 
living organisms including humans, and are toxic to both humans and wildlife. 
Personal information: Any data that can be used to identify an individual, including names, addresses, 
email addresses, identification numbers, location data, and online identifiers. 
Port charges: Fees and dues levied by a port authority on ships, cargo, or passengers for the use of port 
facilities and services. These typically include costs related to a vessel’s entry, stay, and departure as well 
as services provided for handling cargo or passengers. 
Post-clearance audit: A comprehensive review conducted by customs authorities after the release of 
goods. These audits aim to verify the accuracy and compliance of the information declared by traders, such 
as the classification and valuation of goods, and adherence to customs procedures. 
Preferential Trade Agreement (PTA): A treaty between two or more countries where they agree to give 
each other preferential treatment in terms of trade, including tariff reduction or providing other favorable 
terms on a certain range of goods and services. In the context of the WTO, these agreements are referred to 
as Regional Trade Agreements (RTAs). 
Pre-shipment inspection: Compulsory quality, quantity and price control of goods prior to shipment from 
the exporting country, conducted by an independent inspecting agency mandated by the authorities of the 
importing country. 
Price control measure: Measures implemented to control or affect the prices of imported goods to, inter 
alia, support the domestic price of certain products when the import prices of these goods are lower; 
establish the domestic price of certain products because of price fluctuat ion in domestic markets or price 
instability in a foreign market; or to increase or preserve tax revenue, as defined in Chapter F of the 
International Classification of Non-tariff Measures (UNCTAD, 2019). 
Pricing agreements: Arrangements between two or more market participants to coordinate the prices, 
charges, or related terms applied to the goods or services they provide. 
Pricing guideline: Recommendations, schedules, or reference rates issued by government bodies or other 
relevant entities that indicate how service providers should determine or apply fees. These may be binding 
or non-binding and can take the form of suggested tariffs, minimum charges, or pricing formulas intended 
to standardize or influence pricing practices. 
Responsible administrative authority: The government agency or body with the legal power to regulate 
and enforce laws within a specific area of public administration. 
Regulatory impact assessment: Systemic approach to critically assessing the positive and negative effects 
of proposed and existing regulations and non-regulatory alternatives. 
Right to collective bargaining and freedom of association: The labor rights that allow workers to form 
and join organizations of their own choosing (freedom of association) and to negotiate work terms 
collectively with employers (collective bargaining). These rights are fundamental for workers to negotiate

fair wages, safe working conditions, and other employment terms, and are protected by various international 
labor standards. 
Risk management system: A systematic and analytical process used by Customs authorities to identify, 
assess, and manage risks in cross- border trade by applying controls selectively— targeting high -risk 
consignments while expediting the clearance of low-risk goods. 
Rules on anticompetitive practices: Rules that subject agreements between undertakings to competition-
type review of their effects on prices, output, or market conditions, whether under general 
competition/antitrust law or a sector-specific regime providing equivalent oversight. 
Sanitary and Phytosanitary (SPS) measures: Measures such as product quality standards, safety criteria, 
and testing and certification procedures that governments require for products to be placed on the market 
in order to protect human, animal, or plant life or health from risks arising from the in troduction, 
establishment, or spread of pests, diseases, or disease-carrying and disease-causing organisms. 
Science-based risk assessment: A systematic, science-based evaluation of risks to human, animal, or plant 
life or health, proportionate to the appropriate level of protection, that (i) identifies hazards, (ii) evaluates 
likelihood and consequences (exposure/entry/establishment/spread, as relevant), (iii) records data sources, 
methods, and uncertainties, and (iv) produces a written record. 
Standardized international customs documents: Also referred to as carnets, these documents facilitate 
the temporary admission of goods by avoiding extensive customs procedures, eliminating payment of 
customs duties and excise taxes and eliminating the purchase of temporary import bonds. 
Substantially all trade: A free trade agreement or customs union is considered to liberalize substantially 
all trade if it sets customs duties to 0% on ≥85% of tariff lines (HS six-digit or national tariff-line level) and 
does not fully exclude any HS chapter (2- digit) from duty elimination by the end of its scheduled 
implementation period. 
Technical regulation: A measure that lays down mandatory product characteristics — such as design 
features, performance requirements, safety or quality specifications, labelling, packaging, or production 
methods — with which compliance is legally required in order to place a good on the market or import it 
into the economy. 
Technology neutrality principle: The principle that laws, regulations, and policies should remain neutral 
with respect to the choice of technology or medium. A technology- neutral legal framework sets 
requirements in functional terms, without prescribing or excluding specific technological solutions. 
Temporary admission: A customs procedure that permits the import of goods into a country’s territory 
without full payment of customs duties and taxes, provided these goods are intended for re-export within a 
specified period. 
Trade information portal: An information resource provided by Governments to traders in order to obtain, 
from one single source, all the information that importers or exporters in a given country may require in 
order to comply with their regulatory obligations in relation to all the government authorities that control 
export, import or transit business. A TIP can be hosted on an independent website, or on the websites of 
any official public agency (e.g. the Ministry of Commerce or the Customs Administration), as long as all 
the information is presented on a single platform.

Truck booking system : A digital platform that enables the scheduling and management of freight 
transportation by connecting shippers with trucking companies and drivers. 
Trusted trader program: An initiative developed by customs authorities to certify businesses that 
demonstrate high levels of security and compliance with customs regulations as “trusted” partners, and 
granting benefits such as fewer inspections, faster clearance, and simplified procedures. Examples are the 
Authorized Economic Operator (AEO) or the Customs-Trade Partnership Against Terrorism (C-TPAT). 
Trip-based permits or quotas: Trip-based permits are authorizations that allow a foreign road transport 
operator to carry goods on a specific journey into another economy, while quotas set the maximum number 
of such permits that can be issued over a given period. Both are common under bilateral or multilateral road 
transport agreements. 
Ultimate beneficial owners: The natural person(s) who ultimately owns or controls an asset, entity or 
arrangement and who benefits from it, even if the ownership or control is exercised through another person 
or structure. 
Unified border management system: A legal and institutional framework that requires Customs and other 
border agencies to coordinate controls at the border, including through shared risk assessment, joint 
inspections, and exchange of information, with the aim of streamlining clearance procedures and avoiding 
duplicative checks 
Unsolicited commercial electronic messages (spam): Unrequested digital communications, typically sent 
in bulk for advertising or promotional purposes, that are directed to multiple recipients without their prior 
consent. 
Vessel flag: Ships that are registered in a particular economy are authorized to fly the flag of that economy. 
The flag state is also considered the vessel’s nationality and has legal responsibility over it.

CHAPTER 8. TAXATION–METHODOLOGY NOTE 
 
I. MOTIVATION 
 
Taxation is a powerful policy tool that governments use to generate revenues and finance operations, public 
goods, and services. In the private sector, taxation can promote growth and development by financing 
physical infrastructure, human capital investments, law enforcement, and other public services. On the other 
hand, excessive taxation can distort markets, alter investment decisions, and foster tax evasion.1 Likewise, 
cumbersome regulations, complex tax reporting requirements, and inefficient tax procedures may increase 
compliance costs for firms and discourage formalization.2 Identifying the challenges taxpayers face can 
guide reforms that support private sector development while pursuing domestic resource mobilization 
objectives. 
 
According to a cademic research , deficiencies such as complicated tax regulation s,
 inefficient tax 
administration, and high tax compliance costs can affect private sector development.3 The Taxation topic 
indicators include measures that capture these potential issues, as well as measures that focus on 
environmental sustainability. 
 
Digitalization of tax administration services positive ly impacts tax collection.4 Electronic filing services 
contribute to reducing compliance costs and foster a more transparent tax regime by curbing corruption and 
bribe solicitation.5 Digitalization of the tax administration’s procedures also helps reduce tax evasion.6 
 
The efficiency of tax administration system s also impacts the burden of administrative compliance. 
Research shows that economies with efficient tax administration procedures —easily access ible 
information, e -tax systems, effective risk management, and transparency —experience greater firm 
productivity and economic growth.7 Impartial, accessible, and efficient tax dispute resolution mechanisms 
are essential for allowing taxpayers to challenge tax assessments and receive prompt and fair hearing.8 
Finally, improving internal efficiency enables tax administrations to unlock additional revenues.9 
 
In addition to boosting economic performance, taxation can be a powerful tool in promoting environmental 
sustainability. Environmental taxes effectively address market failures in accounting for environmental 
impacts. Carbon pricing allows consumers and businesses to choose cost-effective methods to reduce their 
environmental “footprint” or to incentivize innovation by investing in low-carbon emissions technologies.

II. INDICATORS 
 
The Taxation topic measures the quality of tax regulations, administration, and implementation from a 
firm’s perspective across the three different dimensions, here referred to as pillars. The first pillar assesses 
the quality of tax regulations, covering de jure and de facto information on the legal framework. The second 
pillar measures the quality of tax administration by assessing the tax-related public services. The third pillar 
measures the efficiency of tax regulation and related public services from a firm’s perspective. Each pillar 
is divided into categories—defined by common features that inform the grouping into a particular 
category—and each category is further divided into subcategories. Each subcategory has one or several 
indicators, each of which may, in turn, consist of one or several components. Relevant points are assigned 
to each indicator and subsequently aggregated to obtain the number of points for each subcategory, 
category, and pillar. Table 1 summarizes all three pillars and their respective categories.

The availability of information about general tax registration is a fundamental component of effective tax

III. DATA SOURCES 
 
4.1 Data Collection Sources 
 
The data for Pillar I and Pillar II are collected through consultations with private sector experts. Private 
sector experts include tax advisors, tax consultants, tax accountants, tax lawyers, tax specialists, and tax 
auditors. The data on the time it takes to go through a tax dispute are collected through consultations with 
private sector experts. The reason for this approach is that firms participating in Enterprise Surveys may 
have limited experience with processes that do not occur on a regular basis for most companies (such as 
submitting a tax complaint). Most data for Pillar III are collected through Enterprise Surveys. 
 
Enterprise Surveys provide representative data on the time required for filing and paying taxes, the 
percentage of firms filing and paying taxes electronically, the duration of a generic tax audit, obtaining a 
VAT refund in practice, and effective tax rates for corporate profit -based taxes, and employment-based 
taxes and social contributions (only the financial cost for firms). A representative sample of companies 
captures variation of user experience within each economy. Businesses with different characteristics, such 
as size, region, and sector participate in the surveys. For more details on the collection of data by Enterprise 
Surveys, please refer to the Overview chapter of this Methodology Handbook.

IV. PARAMETERS 
 
To ensure comparability of the data collected from expert consultations across economies, the Taxation 
topic uses general parameters. A parameter refers to an assumption about location, tax residency, sector 
and activity. Questionnaire respondents are presented with these parameters and asked to evaluate a 
standardized scenario that permits comparability across locations, jurisdictions, and economies. 
 
5.1 General Parameters 
 
Tax regulations and their applicability may vary depending on the location , residency status , sector and 
nature of business activity. To strike a balance between cross-economy comparability and economy-specific 
representativeness, the Taxation topic employs the following general parameters to provide contextual 
information for experts to identify the appropriate regulations , services and practices to be assessed in 
different pillars. 
 
5.1.1 Business Location
 
Justification: 
Geographic location determines the applicable local corporate profit-based, consumption, environmental, 
and labor taxes and contributions when taxes are administered at multiple levels or at a local level. These 
factors may affect the availability of online services, the process of tax registration and deregistration, the 
parties involved in the review of tax complaints, and more. Thus, business location is an essential parameter 
for assessing the regulatory framework and public services in taxation. The largest city is chosen based on 
the population size as detailed in the Overview of this Methodology Handbook. 
 
Application: 
For Pillar I, the parameter is used in cases when local regulations are applicable in addition to the national 
ones. In economies where regulations differ across states, the regulations of the largest city are measured. 
For Pillar II, the parameter determine s the applicable taxes and procedures. For Pillar III, it applies only 
when the data are collected through expert consultations rather than Enterprise Surveys. 
 
5.1.2 Tax Residency–Tax Resident of the Assessed Economy 
Justification:

It is common that a jurisdiction’s tax residents and nonresidents (that is, tax residents of another jurisdiction) 
are subjected to different rules, requirements, and regulations. The regulatory framework that applies to tax 
residents of other jurisdictions is often complemented by the double tax treaties. When a double tax treaty 
applies, its details are defined by the agreement between two jurisdictions and may substantially vary across 
parties. The inclusion of nonresidents taxation may, therefore, becom e overly complicated and result in 
data that are hardly comparable. As a result, the Taxation topic focuses only on companies that are tax 
residents of the measured jurisdiction. 
 
Application: 
The parameter of the tax residency is relevant to all measures of the Taxation topic. In Pillar I, it defines 
the applicable rules and regulations, while in Pillar II, the tax residency determines the specific processes, 
procedures, and services that the companies undergo. In Pillar III, this parameter is integral in setting the 
compliance requirements that, in turn, define the time and cost to complete the specific processes. 
 
5.1.3 Sector and Activity–Excluding Mineral, Extractive, and Financial Sectors
 
Justification: 
Taxation of mineral, extractive, and financial sectors can differ from regular taxation in many ways. Mineral 
and extractive industries often involve complex contractual arrangements, such as production sharing 
agreements or joint venture arrangements, that can make taxation more complex. Companies in these 
sectors often operate across borders, which can raise complex international tax issues, such as transfer 
pricing and double tax treaty provisions. These issues may not be relevant for regular companies t hat 
operate only within a single jurisdiction. Additionally, the valuation of mineral and extractive resources can 
be difficult, requiring specialized knowledge and techniques. In the financial sector, the complexity of 
taxation arises given that financial institutions engage in a wide variety of activities—including provision 
of loans, trading, investment banking, and wealth management —often across multiple jurisdictions. 
Furthermore, financial institutions are subject to extensive regulation, which can create additional 
complexity in the tax system. For example, some jurisdictions may offer tax incentives for certain types of 
financial activity, while others may impose additional taxes or reporting requirements. To allow data 
comparability, the Taxation topic excludes matters related to taxation of mineral, extractive, and financial 
sectors. 
 
Application: 
The sector parameter is relevant to all three pillars. The regulatory framework and public services for the 
mineral, extractive, and financial sectors often differ from those applicable to regular companies. Therefore, 
including them could skew the data and reduce comparability. When it comes to efficiency, companies in 
mineral, extractive, and financial sectors often require specialized knowledge and resources to comply with 
taxation, which can be time-consuming and expensive. By excluding them, the Taxation topic can provide 
a more standardized approach to the efficiency of taxation, allowing for better data comparability. 
 
5.2 Specific Parameters 
 
The Taxation topic does not employ specific parameters that are applicable to one or two pillars.

6.3 Pillar III–Efficiency of Tax System in Practice 
 
Pillar III covers 7 indicators with scores ranging from 0 to 100 on firm flexibility (table 37). The scores on 
indicators are assigned to firm flexibility only, because the indicators measure the outcomes of firms’ 
compliance with taxation requirements. For example, spending a significant amount of time to prepare, file, 
and pay corporate income tax, VAT/sales taxes, and social taxes and contributions have adverse impacts 
on firms, thus hampering firm flexibility. The scoring for each category under this pillar is as follows: 
 
6.3.1 Time and Functionality of Processes has 5 indicators with a total maximum score of 50 points. 
Specifically, the Time to Prepare, File, and Pay Taxes Subcategory has 1 indicator , the Use of 
Electronic Systems to File and Pay Taxes Subcategory has 1 indicator, the Duration of Generic Tax 
Audit Subcategory has 1 indicator, the Duration of a Tax Dispute Subcategory has 1 indicator, and 
the Use of VAT Refund Subcategory has 1 indicator. 
 
6.3.2 Financial Burden on Firms has 2 indicators with a total maximum score of 50 points. Specifically, 
the Effective Tax Rate (ETR) for Profit Taxes Subcategory has 1 indicator and the Effective Tax 
Rate (ETR) for Employment-Based Taxes and Social Contributions Subcategory has 1 indicator.

ANNEX B. TAXATION–ANNOTATED QUESTIONNAIRE 
 
Annex B consists of a Glossary and Annotated Questionnaire for Taxation. The Annotated Questionnaire 
provides the mapping between each indicator and the corresponding question(s). 
 
Glossary 
 
Appeal: The process where a higher authority reviews a decision made in a dispute, typically used when 
one party is dissatisfied with the outcome of the initial decision. The higher authority, which can be a higher 
court, an administrative agency, or an independent body, examines the case and makes a new decision. 
 
Carbon pricing instruments (CPIs): Policy instruments that impose a cost on emitting carbon dioxide 
and other greenhouse gases to incentivize emission reductions. While there are many types of CPIs, the two 
main types of CPIs in climate mitigation are carbon taxes and Emissions Trading Systems (ETS), also 
known as cap-and-trade. 
 
Carbon taxes: Tax imposed on carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions or non- renewable fossil fuels based on 
their carbon content. 
 
Complaint on a tax audit assessment: An objection filed by a taxpayer or their representative against the 
outcome of a tax audit conducted by a tax authority. 
 
Consumption-based taxes: Taxes typically levied on the purchase of goods or services , paid directly or 
indirectly by the final consumer. The most common consumption taxes include value added tax (VAT), 
goods and services tax (GST), and sales tax. For the purposes of this questionnaire, these do not include 
excise taxes, import duties, or taxes specific to import. 
 
Core taxes: For the purpose of this questionnaire, core taxes encompass three categories: (1) corporate 
income-based taxes, (2) consumption- based taxes (VAT, GST, or similar consumption taxes), and (3) 
employment-based taxes and social contributions. 
 
Corporate income-based taxes: Taxes levied on a company’s profit or turnover (when a turnover is used 
as a proxy of profit). Taxes that are levied on turnover as a measure of sales are not included here and are 
instead classified as consumption -based taxes. The most common type is corporate income tax (CIT). 
Taxation of mineral, extractive, and financial sectors is excluded from the assessment. 
 
Digital trade: All forms of economic activity conducted via digital networks, including digitally enabled 
transactions of goods and services. This includes services like cloud computing, data storage, and 
processing, as well as the online sale and delivery of goods and services. Digital trade involves both the 
production of digital goods (e.g., software, digital media, and online services) and the use of digital 
processes to facilitate traditional trade (e.g., e-commerce, online ordering, and electronic payments). It may 
also involve consumers, firms, and governments. 
 
Direct emission approach: An approach to carbon taxation where the tax is levied directly on the amount 
of carbon emissions produced. 
 
E-invoicing: A system for generating, transmitting, and processing invoices electronically using a 
standardized digital format (e.g., XML, JSON, EDIFACT, PEPPOL BIS). This excludes invoices in PDF, 
Word/Excel, or scanned formats. E-invoicing facilitates real-time, or near real-time, data sharing with tax 
administrations, supporting automatic pre-filling of tax returns.

Electronic filing (e-filing): The process of submitting tax returns via the internet using computers or mobile 
devices, without requiring any physical interactions (with tax authority, banks, or any other parties). If hard 
copies of tax returns are required to be stored (e.g., for audit purposes) or submitted, it is not considered as 
an electronic filing. 
 
Electronic payment (e-payment): A payment request submitted online via computers or mobile devices, 
without requiring physical interactions (with a bank, tax authority, or any other parties). Examples include 
online banking, direct payments on tax authority websites, etc. If hard copies of payment transactions 
records are required to be stored or submitted in person, it is not considered an electronic payment. 
 
Emission trading system (ETS): A carbon pricing instrument where emitters receive emission allowances 
or permits that can be traded with other emitters. It sets a cap on total emissions within a specific area and 
allocates permits to emission sources through auctions, free allowances, o r both. Emitters can use their 
permits or sell them to others. 
 
Employment-based taxes and social contributions: Employer-reported levies on employee headcount or 
compensation, including salaries, wages, and benefits. This includes all employment related taxes and social 
contributions reported by the employer, either remitted directly or withheld from employees’ sala ries. 
Personal income taxes are included only if they are withheld and reported by employer. Social contributions 
may include payments to unemployment insurance, pension funds, disability insurance, medical insurance 
and similar contributions. 
 
Feedback from taxpayer: Feedback from corporate taxpayers that is proactively requested and obtained 
by independent third parties or tax administration. This can take form of focus groups, surveys, online 
feedback platforms, panels, and forums. 
 
Financial performance: A measurement of tax administration’s overall financial efficiency, typically 
presented in financial performance reports on an annual basis. These reports offer a detailed overview of 
the financial activities, achievements, and efficiency of a tax administ ration over a specific period. They 
evaluate key metrics such as revenue collection and expenditure details and often include the financial 
statements of the tax administration, along with compliance and enforcement statistics. 
 
Fossil fuel subsidies: Policy instruments that directly or indirectly reduce the price paid by end users for 
fossil fuels or the energy generated from them. These subsidies may apply to primary fuels (such as coal, 
crude oil, and natural gas) and secondary energy (such as electricity and heating). Dire ct subsidies lower 
consumer prices through monetary transfers. Indirect subsidies include tax expenditures, price controls, 
discounts, or other measures that prevent full cost recovery, thereby artificially reducing end- user prices 
and creating distortions in energy access, pricing, and competitiveness. For the purposes of B-READY, the 
measurement of fossil fuel subsidies is limited to consumer-side support mechanisms that reduce end-user 
prices. While producer -side measures (e.g., tax breaks for exploration and extraction) also constitute 
subsidies, they fall outside the scope of this assessment, which does not cover the oil and gas industry. 
 
General tax guidance: I nformation and instructions provided by tax authorities to assist taxpayers 
understand and comply with tax laws and regulations. This can be in the form of tax guides, tax briefs, 
practice notes, and factsheets, which clarify tax obligations, explain filing requirements, and provide 
practical advice for managing t ax-related matters effectively. It is typically informational and not legally 
binding. 
 
Independent complaint review mechanism: Structurally and functionally independent body or unit 
within a tax administration that adjudicates taxpayer complaints on tax audit assessments. Such a body or 
unit is considered independent only if staff/officers who conduct the review have not participa ted in the

taxpayer’s audit. Furthermore, independence requires that the review is not conducted by the head of the 
tax administration or any unit reporting directly to the audit unit. However, the review may be conducted 
by a separate unit that reports to the head of the tax administration, as long as it is organizationally distinct 
from the audit unit. 
 
Internal tax guidance: Guidelines produced specifically for tax administration staff, detailing policies and 
procedures they should follow in their duties. These provide technical advice issued internally to help staff 
understand and apply tax laws and regulations consistently a cross different tax offices or units. Examples 
include revenue procedure, internal revenue manuals, and technical advice memorandums. 
 
Legislative or administrative act: Legal instruments enacted by a legislative or administrative bodies with 
general binding force at any government level (e.g., federal, state, or municipal) or administrative level 
(ministry of finance, tax authority). These include codes, laws, statutes, regulations, ordinances, and 
decrees. 
 
Local tax representative : An individual or entity appointed to act on behalf of a taxpayer in a specific 
jurisdiction, responsible for fulfilling the taxpayer's VAT/GST obligations. Some economies require a local 
tax representative when suppliers have tax obligations but no physical presence in the jurisdiction. 
 
Measurement, reporting, and verification (MRV): A system used in carbon pricing that allows to record 
carbon emissions. MRV systems can operate at the facility level or at the sector level. At the facility level 
each facility is responsible for tracking its fuel usage, estimating emissions based on carbon content and 
reporting this information to the relevant government agency. At the sector level emissions are aggregated 
and assessed across an entire industry or sector. While individual facilities may not report emissions 
directly, they may be required to maintain internal records or report production volumes, fuel use or energy 
consumption to support sector-level estimates. 
 
Operational performance: A measurement of tax administration’s operational efficiency, typically 
presented in operational performance reports on an annual basis. These reports evaluate the tax authority’s 
core functions and processes, including metrics on management and accountability, taxpayer services (e.g., 
assistance programs, filing services, educational outreach), and enforcement activities. It may also cover 
the organizational structure, leadership roles, and strategic initiatives aimed to enhance op erational 
efficiency and effectiveness. 
 
Pre-filled electronic declaration: Preparation or pre-filling of a tax declaration by the tax administration, 
using information from third parties (such as banks and financial institutions, suppliers, etc.), as well as 
from previously submitted tax declarations, or directly from the taxpayers’ tax accounting if such data 
sharing is established. Also referred to as ‘pre- populated declarations,’ these declarations substantially 
simplify the effort required by corporate taxpayers for annual tax filing. The bas ic pre-filled information 
can include corporate taxpayer’s registration details, estimated income and expenses, and taxes withheld or 
paid in advance. Advanced pre-filled information includes the calculation of final tax liability or other near-
final calculations. 
 
Private binding rulings: Binding statements written by the government (tax authority or other dedicated 
institution) in response to specific requests from corporate taxpayers seeking clarification about tax 
treatment of a planned or completed transaction or other specific circumstances. Corporate taxpayers who 
followed the ruling cannot be later penalized by the tax authority, even if the ruling is retroactively deemed 
incorrect. In some jurisdictions, these are known as “advance rulings.” For the purposes of this 
questionnaire, advance rulings are included only if any corporate taxpayer can request such a ruling.

Private sector stakeholders: Firms, business organizations, trade and consumer organizations, tax 
advisors, private sector technical and environmental experts, and others as applicable. 
 
Public binding rulings: Published statements describing how particular situations should be treated for tax 
purposes. Corporate taxpayers who followed the ruling cannot be later penalized by the tax authority, even 
if the ruling is retroactively deemed incorrect. General tax guidance or instructions are not considered public 
binding rulings. Public binding rulings address very specific transactions rather than provide broad 
explanations of how the tax authority interprets or applies the law. 
 
Single-entry bookkeeping: A bookkeeping method where each transaction is recorded as a single-entry in 
the tax journal. It is generally used for cash-based accounting. 
 
Tax audit manuals and guidelines: Comprehensive documents intended to guide auditors in conducting 
audits of corporate taxpayers. They provide a framework for planning, preparation, and executing tax 
audits, as well as preparing reports and results. These also describe methods and techniques for assessing 
the correctness of a taxpayer’s liability, as well as the principles, standards, and code of ethics for auditors. 
 
Tax audit plan: A strategic framework outlining the tax administration's annual plan for conducting audits. 
It typically includes information on audit coverage for various taxes and key taxpayer segments, selection 
of audit cases (e.g., by prioritizing high-risk areas and centrally selecting cases based on risk assessments), 
types of audits to be conducted, allocation of resources and timeline. The plan must contain at least the 
selection criteria, but it is not required that an explicit list of taxpayers that will be audited is published. 
 
Tax ombudsman: An independent, non-judicial entity focused on recommending solutions for taxpayer 
complaints, distinct from judicial bodies that provide formal judicial processes. The ombudsman has the 
authority to investigate service -related complaints, including mistakes, omissions, oversights, or other 
administrative issues, and can make suggestions to the tax administration. It must be independent from the 
tax administration and must possess expertise in tax-related matters to review tax cases. It can be a separate 
body or a division within a general ombudsman’s office. 
 
Tax records: Documents created exclusively or partially for tax purposes. Tax records often include VAT 
invoices, tax books and records, tax declarations/returns, payment slips, and any other documentation 
required to verify reported income, expenses, credits, and deductions. These may include financial records 
that businesses normally maintain (e.g., balance sheets, profit and loss accounts, cash flow statements, 
invoices receipts, asset records, etc.) if such records are required to be submitted to the tax authority 
regularly or upon request. 
 
Taxpayer portal: An electronic gateway that uses secure authentication to provide corporate taxpayers and 
their authorized agents with online access to tax information, services, and functions. Such portal is 
different from the general website as it enables users to update bank account and/or contact details (e.g., 
address and telephone number); view, prepare, file, and adjust tax reporting documents; make financial 
transactions (e.g., pay taxes and request refunds); communicate with the tax administration via secure 
channels; and access historical files and communication. 
 
Unified Identification Number (UIN): A unique identifier assigned to a corporate taxpayer by a public 
agency or regulatory body to streamline tracking and management of their affairs. It may be part of a 
Unified Business Identifier (UBI), which goes beyond taxation to include business registration, licensing, 
and other r egulatory requirements, aiming to eliminate multiple identification numbers across different 
regulatory regimes.

CHAPTER 9. DISPUTE RESOLUTION–METHODOLOGY NOTE 
 
I. MOTIVATION 
 
In developed and developing economies alike, commercial disputes inevitably occur. Adverse economic 
outcomes for the private sector, ranging from reduced entrepreneurial activity and lower investment to 
macroeconomic volatility, can arise when these disputes cannot be adequately resolved.1 This makes a well-
functioning dispute resolution system essential for a healthy business environment. Such a system requires 
efficiency and quality.2 
 
Having time- and cost-effective mechanisms for resolving disputes is critical because excessively long and 
expensive proceedings may defeat the very purpose of bringing a case to formal institutions, making them 
unattractive and unaffordable.
3 In fact, correlations have been established between judicial efficiency and 
facilitated entrepreneurial activity. 4 Evidence also suggests that under a more effective court system , 
businesses are likely to have greater access to finance and borrow more.5 In addition, expeditious judiciaries 
are associated with higher levels of domestic and foreign investment. 6 When investors know that, in case 
of nonperformance of an obligation, their claim will be considered in a timely manner, they may have more 
incentives to increase investment. 7 Also, enhancing the efficiency of the judiciary may strengthen 
competition and foster innovation.8 
 
The quality of the dispute resolution process also matters.
9 Claims should be considered with due care by 
credible institutions capable of issuing sound judgments. 10 In economies with low confidence in court 
systems, firms are less willing to expand their businesses and look for alternative trade partners.11 To attract 
more investors, economies should ensure not only judiciaries’ effectiveness but also their strength and 
reliability.12 Limited enforceability of contracts is associated with the suboptimal distribution of resources, 
the use of inefficient technologies, and greater macroeconomic volatility. 13 Because poor commercial 
dispute resolution might deprive firms of timely and full payments, liquidity and insolvency issues can 
follow, as can subsequent bankruptcies and unemployment.14 
 
Efficient and quality dispute resolution systems require a clear and up- to-date regulatory framework and 
enhanced public services. 15 Robust laws and regulations are vital because they lay the foundation for 
resolving disputes in a timely and trustworthy manner.16 Well-designed regulatory frameworks must be put 
into effect through a sound public services system. 17 Key elements of such a system include solid 
organizational structure , high degree of digitalization, increased transparency, and advanced services 
related to alternative dispute resolution (ADR). 18 In light of this, the Dispute Resolution topic focuses on 
quality of regulations and public services, as well as the operational efficiency with which these are applied 
in practice. 
 
II. INDICATORS 
 
The Dispute Resolution topic measures the efficiency and quality of the resolution of commercial 
disputes—those arising in the business context between firms—across three different dimensions, referred 
to as pillars. The first pillar assesses the adequacy of legislation pertaining to both court processes and 
alternative dispute resolution, covering de jure features that are necessary for the efficient processing of 
cases, facilitated resolution of cross- border claims, creating alternative venues for settling disputes, and 
ensuring trust in relevant institutions. The second pillar measures judicial organizational structure, courts’ 
digitalization and transparency, as well as ADR -related services, thus capturing the de facto provision of 
public services. The third pillar measures the reliability of dispute resolution, the time and cost required to 
resolve a dispute, as well as the time and cost associated with the recognition and enforcement of decisions. 
Each pillar is divided into categories —defined by common features that inform the grouping into a 
particular category—and each category is further divided into subcategories. Each subcategory has several

indicators, each of which may, in turn, consist of one or several components. Relevant points are assigned 
to each indicator and subsequently aggregated to obtain the number of points for each subcategory, 
category, and pillar. Table 1 summarizes all three pillars and their respective categories.

1.1.1 Procedural Certainty 
Increasing procedural certainty in dispute resolution tends to facilitate the conduct of proceedings and 
prevent deadlocks.
19 For example, time standards for specific key processes may address some of the most 
common inefficiencies in litigation, such as the ones related to serving a complaint on the defendant or 
preparing an expert opinion.20 In a similar vein, specifying a time limit, after which evidence can generally 
no longer be submitted, is likely to speed up the consideration of cases. 21 Another important procedural

safeguard is to have limitations on adjournments that the judge can grant. 22 Crucially, holding a pre -trial 
conference is equally associated with procedural certainty.23 The dispute resolution process may be further 
streamlined when the judge has the powers to issue a default judgment in case a duly notified defendant 
fails to respond to a court summons or appear in court.24 
 
To streamline international dispute resolution, it is important to lay down clear and straightforward rules 
on the circulation of public documents and recognition of foreign judgments. For example, such rules permit 
the use of apostilles and ensure that the local court is not allowed to review foreign judgments on the 
merits.25 As to enforcement proceedings, they can be facilitated by providing enforcement agents with 
explicit powers to seize more classes of assets, such as the debtor’s monetary claims toward a third party, 
financial instruments, or electronic assets (such as cry ptocurrency).

1.1.2 Judicial Competence (includes gender and environment) 
Judicial integrity is key to ensur ing public trust in the dispute resolution system. Businesses may avoid 
courts altogether if they perceive them as unreliable, biased, or corrupt.27 Incorporating good practices that 
strengthen the independence and impartiality of judges into the law is essential for judicial integrity.28 For 
example, protections should be put in place to protect judges from interference with the adjudication of 
their cases by the chairperson of a court, as well as from being subjected them to disciplinary proceedings 
for reasons solely related to how they apply and interpret the law.29 Requiring judges to disclose their assets 
may contribute positively to their accountability.30 
 
Codified targeted instruments—such as the code of ethics for judges or the code of ethics for enforcement 
agents—also help promote integrity.
31 Economies may further enhance courts’ reliability through enacting 
a judicial whistleblowing policy. 32 To ensure equal justice under the law, the dispute resolution system 
should serve as an example in the area of gender inclusion . This implies making it possible for women to 
participate in proceedings on equal footing with men.33

it is critical to ensure that relevant environmental disputes are also settled promptly and thoroughly.

1.2.1 Legal Safeguards in Arbitration 
Arbitration is an alternative dispute resolution mechanism that is widely used by firms to resolve their 
commercial disputes.
35 To benefit fully from arbitration, it is important to provide broad access to 
arbitration. For example, the law can tackle this issue by removing restrictions for public bodies and state-
owned enterprises to use arbitration in resolving commercial and investment disputes.36 Ensuring the right 
to freely choose legal counsel or allowing third-party funding to help smaller businesses cover their legal 
costs can increase openness of arbitration proceedings.37 
 
Another key element of a robust regulatory framework on arbitration is the recognition of the “kompetenz-
kompetenz” principle, which empowers an arbitral tribunal to rule on its own jurisdiction and requires 
domestic courts to defer to the arbitral tribunal on this question.

the primary role in a ny dispute resolution system, court support is crucial for making arbitration truly 
attractive, in particular, in the collection of evidence. 39 Moreover, the attractiveness of arbitration can be 
further enhanced if the legislation sets out a straightforward, up -to-date, and predictable regime for 
recognizing and enforcing arbitral awards. Such a regime allows for recognition and enforcement of interim 
and partial awards as well as ensures that domestic and foreign awards may not be reviewed on the grounds

Category 2.1 is divided into three subcategories consisting of several indicators, each of which may, in turn, 
have several components. 
 
2.1.1 Organizational Structure of Courts 
Effective and reliable dispute resolution processes are conditional upon having a robust organizational 
structure. Within such a framework, aspects of court specialization, access to justice, and integrity play an 
essential role.
45 Ensuring that commercial cases are handled by specialized courts or divisions at the level 
of first instance may have a positive impact on the efficiency and quality of dispute resolution. 46 Due to 
their unique nature, international cases may benefit from increased specialization too. This can be ensured 
by establishing a court or division of a court dedicated to hearing international commercial matters and 
setting up a public agency or government unit tasked specifically with the prevention and early resolution 
of investor-state disputes.47 
 
Access to justice matters in commercial litigation too, with micro and small businesses being particularly 
vulnerable in this regard.48 To ensure access to justice for all market participants, economies may establish 
small claims courts or procedures, as well as create legal aid programs targeting entrepreneurs who cannot 
afford legal costs.49 Furthermore, in administering justice, complaints may often arise with respect to how 
the dispute resolution system is organized and how cases are handled in practice. If left unaddressed, these 
complaints may lead to a decline in institutional credibility and cause procedural inefficiencies. It is , 
therefore, critical to set up specific and independent review mechanisms that would allow aggrieved parties 
to submit their complaints regarding judicial misconduct or the misconduct of enforcement agents.

2.1.2 Digitalization of Court Processes 
A key lesson from the COVID -19 pandemic for dispute resolution is that digit alization may have a 
substantial effect on ensuring access to justice and the streamlining of proceedings. Through technological 
advancement, litigants should be allowed to file and be served with court documents electronically. This 
includes filing and service during the commencement of proceedings and in all subsequent stages, extending 
to the receipt of court decisions in an electronic format .
51 When relevant, it is equally important to ensure

2.1.3 Transparency of Courts (includes gender) 
Transparency is fundamental for building trust in the judiciary. A transparent dispute resolution system is 
associated with an increased degree of public control over courts and proceedings, and it provides the parties 
with more certainty about the handling of their cases. This starts with ensuring that all legal instruments 
(laws, regulations, directives, orders, and so on) are published free of charge.
56 Apart from laws and 
regulations, it is also vital to publish judgments of both first instance and higher courts.57 As to the conduct 
of proceedings, the principle of transparency requires granting public access to hearings, whether they are 
held in person or online.58 
 
The credibility of the judiciary may further grow if the dispute resolution system demonstrates a 
commitment to collecting and publishing information about its organization and performance. To begin 
with, it is important to make publicly available the statistics on the number of judges, providing for 
disaggregation by the individual court, the level of the court, as well as by the sex of the judges.
59 Further, 
it is essential to produce and release key statistics about performance, such as data on the time it takes to 
adjudicate different categories of cases and the number of cases resolved versus the number of incoming 
cases.
60 Publication of information is of no less significance in enforcement, where data on the average 
length of proceedings and number of resolved and unresolved cases represents a particular interest. 61

2.2 Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR)

2.2.1 Public Services for Arbitration (includes gender) 
In commercial dispute resolution, businesses can benefit from having access to alternative mechanisms, 
whether they are provided directly by the government or through private sector proxies. ADR mechanisms, 
such as arbitration and mediation, are typically more flexible than courts and thus may be better suited to 
the parties’ specific needs. Considering their wide use, arbitration services —for both domestic and 
international cases—stand out as particularly important.
62 The availability of such services is confirmed by 
the existence of actual commercial cases resolved through arbitration. 63 Arbitration can be made more 
attractive if the arbitration institution provide s for special procedures intended to make the process more 
efficient. These include emergency arbitration, early dismissal, expedited (fast -track) arbitration, and 
consolidation of related arbitral proceedings and joinder of additional parties.64 
 
To further promote arbitration, a roster of qualified arbitrators may be set up , while also ensuring that 
choosing arbitrators outside the roster is not prohibited.
65 According to a different good practice, arbitration

the latest trends, arbitration services should embrace digit alization, which includes developing a relevant 
online platform, enabling virtual conferences and hearings, and introducing electronic signing.67 Moreover, 
transparency is critical for the credibility of arbitration. This fosters arbitration institutions to collect and 
disclose statistics on the number of handled cases, time to resolve disputes, number of appointments of 
arbitrators disaggregated by sex, as well as to publish summaries of arbitral awards. 68 Therefore,
